data.title: Python for Beginners
data.description: Learn Python programming from scratch. This course covers fundamentals, data structures, functions, and object-oriented programming.

modules.title: Getting Started with Python
modules.description: Introduction to Python and setting up your development environment

content_data.transcript:
Welcome to Python programming! In this video, we'll explore why Python is one of the most popular programming languages in the world.

Python is known for:
• Clean, readable syntax
• Extensive standard library
• Large community and ecosystem
• Versatile applications (web, data science, AI, automation)

By the end of this course, you'll be able to write your own Python programs!

content_data.main_content:
Setting Up Your Python Environment

Step 1: Download Python

Visit python.org/downloads and download Python 3.12 or later.

Windows Installation

  1. Run the installer
  2. Important: Check ✅ "Add Python to PATH"
  3. Click "Install Now"

Mac Installation

  1. Download the macOS installer
  2. Run the .pkg file
  3. Follow the installation wizard

Step 2: Verify Installation

Open Terminal (Mac) or Command Prompt (Windows) and type:

python --version

You should see: Python 3.12.x

Step 3: Install VS Code

  1. Download from code.visualstudio.com
  2. Install the Python extension by Microsoft
  3. Create a new file with .py extension

Step 4: Test Your Setup

Create a file called test.py with this content:

print("Python is working!")

Run it with: python test.py

Your First Python Program

Exercise 1: Hello World

Write a program that prints "Hello, World!" to the console.

# Exercise 1: Hello World
print("Hello, World!")

Exercise 2: Personal Greeting

Modify your program to print a personalized greeting with your name.

# Exercise 2: Personal Greeting
print("Hello, my name is Alex!")

Exercise 3: Multiple Lines

Print multiple pieces of information on separate lines:

# Exercise 3: Multiple Lines
print("Alex")
print("Python")
print("I want to automate boring tasks!")

Hint: Use the print() function for each line.

modules.title: Variables and Data Types
modules.description: Understanding variables, strings, numbers, and basic data types

content_data.transcript:
Variables are containers for storing data values.

In Python, you don't need to declare variable types - Python figures it out automatically!

Examples:
name = "John"      # String
age = 25           # Integer
height = 5.9       # Float
is_student = True  # Boolean

Variable naming rules:
• Must start with a letter or underscore
• Can contain letters, numbers, underscores
• Case-sensitive (name ≠ Name)
• Cannot use Python keywords

content_data.main_content:
Numbers in Python

Integer (int)

Whole numbers without decimal points:

age = 25
count = -10
big_number = 1_000_000  # Underscore for readability

Float

Numbers with decimal points:

price = 19.99
temperature = -5.5
pi = 3.14159

Arithmetic Operations

OperatorDescriptionExampleResult
+Addition5 + 38
-Subtraction5 - 32
*Multiplication5 * 315
/Division5 / 31.666...
//Floor Division5 // 31
%Modulus5 % 32
**Exponent5 ** 3125

Useful Functions

abs(-5)      # 5 (absolute value)
round(3.7)   # 4 (round to nearest integer)
max(1, 5, 3) # 5 (maximum value)
min(1, 5, 3) # 1 (minimum value)

content_data.transcript:
Strings are sequences of characters enclosed in quotes.

Creating strings:
name = 'John'           # Single quotes
message = "Hello"        # Double quotes
paragraph = '''Multi
line string'''           # Triple quotes

String operations:
full_name = first + " " + last  # Concatenation
repeat = "Ha" * 3               # "HaHaHa"
length = len(name)              # Get length

String methods:
name.upper()    # "JOHN"
name.lower()    # "john"
name.title()    # "John"

content_data.main_content:
Python Data Types Summary

Basic Data Types

TypeExampleDescription
int42Integer numbers
float3.14Decimal numbers
str"Hello"Text strings
boolTrue/FalseBoolean values

Type Checking

type(42)       # 
type(3.14)     # 
type("Hello")  # 
type(True)     #

Type Conversion

int("42")      # 42 (string to int)
float("3.14")  # 3.14 (string to float)
str(42)        # "42" (int to string)
bool(1)        # True (int to bool)

modules.title: Control Flow
modules.description: If statements, loops, and program flow control

content_data.transcript:
For loops let you repeat code for each item in a sequence.

Looping through a range:
for i in range(5):
    print(i)  # Prints 0, 1, 2, 3, 4

Looping through a list:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for fruit in fruits:
    print(fruit)

Looping with index:
for i, fruit in enumerate(fruits):
    print(f"{i}: {fruit}")

Range variations:
range(5)        # 0, 1, 2, 3, 4
range(2, 5)     # 2, 3, 4
range(0, 10, 2) # 0, 2, 4, 6, 8

content_data.main_content:
While Loops in Python

While loops repeat code as long as a condition is true.

Basic While Loop

count = 0
while count < 5:
    print(count)
    count += 1
# Output: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4

User Input Loop

while True:
    answer = input("Continue? (yes/no): ")
    if answer.lower() == "no":
        break
    print("Continuing...")

Loop Control

break - Exit the loop entirely

for i in range(10):
    if i == 5:
        break
    print(i)  # Prints 0, 1, 2, 3, 4

continue - Skip to next iteration

for i in range(5):
    if i == 2:
        continue
    print(i)  # Prints 0, 1, 3, 4

FizzBuzz Challenge

FizzBuzz is a classic programming challenge!

The Problem

Write a program that prints numbers from 1 to 20, but:

  • For multiples of 3, print "Fizz" instead
  • For multiples of 5, print "Buzz" instead
  • For multiples of both 3 and 5, print "FizzBuzz"

Solution

for i in range(1, 21):
    if i % 3 == 0 and i % 5 == 0:
        print("FizzBuzz")
    elif i % 3 == 0:
        print("Fizz")
    elif i % 5 == 0:
        print("Buzz")
    else:
        print(i)

Expected Output

1, 2, Fizz, 4, Buzz, Fizz, 7, 8, Fizz, Buzz, 11, Fizz, 13, 14, FizzBuzz, 16, 17, Fizz, 19, Buzz

Hint: Use the modulo operator (%) to check divisibility.

data.title: Web Development with React
data.description: Build modern web applications with React. Learn components, hooks, state management, and best practices.

content_data.transcript:
React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces, created by Facebook.

Key features:
• Component-based architecture
• Virtual DOM for performance
• Declarative programming style
• One-way data flow
• Large ecosystem (React Router, Redux, etc.)

React lets you build encapsulated components that manage their own state, then compose them to make complex UIs.

content_data.main_content:
React Components & JSX

What is JSX?

JSX is a syntax extension that looks like HTML but works inside JavaScript:

const element = <h1>Hello, World!</h1>;

Function Components

The simplest way to define a React component:

function Welcome(props) {
  return <h1>Hello, {props.name}!</h1>;
}

// With destructuring
function Welcome({ name }) {
  return <h1>Hello, {name}!</h1>;
}

Using Components

function App() {
  return (
    <div>
      <Welcome name="Alice" />
      <Welcome name="Bob" />
    </div>
  );
}

content_data.transcript:
Props and State are fundamental concepts in React.

PROPS (Properties):
• Passed from parent to child
• Read-only (immutable)
• Used to configure components

STATE:
• Managed within the component
• Can be changed (mutable)
• Changes trigger re-renders

useState is the most common React Hook for managing state.

Basic usage:
const [count, setCount] = useState(0);

Updating state:
setCount(5);           // Set to specific value
setCount(prev => prev + 1);  // Based on previous

content_data.main_content:
useEffect Hook

useEffect lets you perform side effects in function components.

Basic Syntax

useEffect(() => {
  // Effect code here
  return () => {
    // Cleanup code (optional)
  };
}, [dependencies]);

Dependency Array Patterns

// Runs after every render
useEffect(() => { });

// Runs once on mount
useEffect(() => { }, []);

// Runs when count changes
useEffect(() => { }, [count]);

Building a Counter App

Requirements

  • Display the current count
  • Increment button (+1)
  • Decrement button (-1)
  • Reset button (back to 0)

Solution

import { useState, useEffect } from 'react';

function Counter() {
  const [count, setCount] = useState(0);
  
  useEffect(() => {
    document.title = `Count: ${count}`;
  }, [count]);
  
  const increment = () => setCount(prev => prev + 1);
  const decrement = () => setCount(prev => Math.max(0, prev - 1));
  const reset = () => setCount(0);
  
  return (
    <div className="counter">
      <h1>Count: {count}</h1>
      <button onClick={decrement}>-</button>
      <button onClick={reset}>Reset</button>
      <button onClick={increment}>+</button>
    </div>
  );
}

data.title: Introduction to Machine Learning
data.description: Start your journey into machine learning. Learn algorithms, model training, and practical applications with Python.

content_data.transcript: Machine Learning is a subset of AI that enables computers to learn from data without being explicitly programmed.

content_data.main_content:
Types of Machine Learning

1. Supervised Learning

Learning from labeled data where we know the correct answers.

2. Unsupervised Learning

Finding patterns in unlabeled data.

3. Reinforcement Learning

Learning through trial and error with rewards and penalties.

ML Industry Trends

1. Large Language Models (LLMs)

GPT, Claude, and their applications for text generation and understanding.

2. AutoML

Automated model selection and hyperparameter tuning.

3. Edge ML

Running models on mobile devices with TensorFlow Lite and Core ML.

4. Ethical AI

Bias detection, explainable AI, and responsible development.

5. MLOps

Model deployment, monitoring, and CI/CD for ML pipelines.

content_data.transcript: Linear Regression predicts continuous values using linear relationships.

content_data.main_content:
House Price Prediction

The Problem

Build a simple house price predictor using Linear Regression.

Data

sizes = [1000, 1200, 1400, 1600, 1800, 2000]
prices = [200000, 240000, 280000, 320000, 360000, 400000]

Solution

import numpy as np
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression

X = np.array(sizes).reshape(-1, 1)
y = np.array(prices)

model = LinearRegression()
model.fit(X, y)

# Predict price for 1500 sq ft house
prediction = model.predict([[1500]])
print(f"Price: ${prediction[0]:,.0f}")

data.title: SQL Database Fundamentals
data.description: Master SQL queries and database management. Learn to create, read, update, and delete data effectively.

modules.title: SQL Basics
modules.description: Introduction to SQL and basic queries

content_data.transcript: A database is an organized collection of data stored electronically.

content_data.main_content:
SELECT Statements

SELECT retrieves data from one or more tables.

Basic Syntax

SELECT column1, column2
FROM table_name;

Select All Columns

SELECT * FROM users;

WHERE Clause

SELECT * FROM users WHERE status = 'active';

ORDER BY

SELECT * FROM products ORDER BY price DESC;

SQL Query Examples

Given Table: employees

Columns: id, first_name, last_name, email, department, salary, hire_date

Common Queries

1. Select all employees

SELECT * FROM employees;

2. Select names and emails

SELECT first_name, last_name, email FROM employees;

3. Filter by department

SELECT * FROM employees WHERE department = 'Engineering';

4. Top 5 highest paid

SELECT * FROM employees ORDER BY salary DESC LIMIT 5;

5. Count by department

SELECT department, COUNT(*) as count
FROM employees
GROUP BY department;
